t: Blessed is the man that walketh not in the counsel of the ungodly, nor standeth in the way of sinners, nor sitteth in the seat of the scornful.
query: What qualities characterize a person who avoids the influence of the ungodly?

t: And he shall be like a tree planted by the rivers of water, that bringeth forth his fruit in his season; his leaf also shall not wither; and whatsoever he doeth shall prosper.
query: How does a person who delights in the law of the Lord experience personal growth and success?

t: The ungodly are not so: but are like the chaff which the wind driveth away.
query: In what ways are the ungodly compared to chaff in terms of their stability and worth?

t: For the LORD knoweth the way of the righteous: but the way of the ungodly shall perish.
query: What is the ultimate fate of those who do not follow the righteous path?

t: Why do the heathen rage, and the people imagine a vain thing?
query: What motivates people to resist authority and challenge established norms?

t: He that sitteth in the heavens shall laugh: the LORD shall have them in derision.
query: How does the concept of divine judgment affect the actions of worldly rulers?

t: Be wise now therefore, O ye kings: be instructed, ye judges of the earth.
query: What is the significance of divine kingship in the context of governance and power?

t: Kiss the Son, lest he be angry, and ye perish from the way, when his wrath is kindled but a little. Blessed are all they that put their trust in him.
query: What consequences might arise from rejecting a higher moral authority?

t: Many there be which say of my soul, There is no help for him in God. Selah.
query: How can a person find strength and comfort during times of distress?

t: I laid me down and slept; I awaked; for the LORD sustained me.
query: What role does faith play in overcoming fear of adversity?

t: Arise, O LORD; save me, O my God: for thou hast smitten all mine enemies upon the cheek bone; thou hast broken the teeth of the ungodly.
query: How does personal integrity influence one's standing in times of trouble?

t: But know that the LORD hath set apart him that is godly for himself: the LORD will hear when I call unto him.
query: What psychological effects can distress have on a person’s well-being?

t: Hearken unto the voice of my cry, my King, and my God: for unto thee will I pray.
query: What motivates individuals to act unjustly against others?

t: But as for me, I will come into thy house in the multitude of thy mercy: and in thy fear will I worship toward thy holy temple.
query: How can trust in a higher power provide reassurance in difficult situations?

t: But let all those that put their trust in thee rejoice: let them ever shout for joy, because thou defendest them: let them also that love thy name be joyful in thee.
query: What consequences might arise from denying one’s own wrongdoing?

t: Have mercy upon me, O LORD; for I am weak: O LORD, heal me; for my bones are vexed.
query: How does personal righteousness shape one's interactions with others?

t: I am weary with my groaning; all the night make I my bed to swim; I water my couch with my tears.
query: What lessons can be learned from the failures of those who engage in deceitful practices?

t: Lest he tear my soul like a lion, rending it in pieces, while there is none to deliver.
query: How can faith offer support during moments of despair?

t: If I have rewarded evil unto him that was at peace with me; (yea, I have delivered him that without cause is mine enemy:)
query: In what ways can hope for justice provide strength in times of trouble?

t: Why standest thou afar off, O LORD? why hidest thou thyself in times of trouble?
query: How can I seek justice in a world where the wicked seem to prosper?

t: The wicked in his pride doth persecute the poor: let them be taken in the devices that they have imagined.
query: What can I do to remind myself of my own humanity in the face of pride and oppression?

t: For the wicked boasteth of his heart's desire, and blesseth the covetous, whom the LORD abhorreth.
query: How do I cope with feelings of abandonment during difficult times?

t: The wicked, through the pride of his countenance, will not seek after God: God is not in all his thoughts.
query: What steps can I take to stand up for those who are vulnerable?

t: His ways are always grievous; thy judgments are far above out of his sight: as for all his enemies, he puffeth at them.
query: How does pride impact one's ability to seek help or acknowledge wrongs?

t: He hath said in his heart, I shall not be moved: for I shall never be in adversity.
query: In what ways can a person remain humble in a competitive environment?

t: He sitteth in the lurking places of the villages: in the secret places doth he murder the innocent: his eyes are privily set against the poor.
query: How can I be a protector for those who cannot defend themselves?

t: Arise, O LORD; O God, lift up thine hand: forget not the humble.
query: What does it mean to trust in a higher power when faced with adversity?

t: Break thou the arm of the wicked and the evil man: seek out his wickedness till thou find none.
query: How can I stay grounded and not lose hope in a corrupt world?

t: In the LORD put I my trust: how say ye to my soul, Flee as a bird to your mountain?
query: How can I maintain integrity in a society that often rewards deceit?

t: If the foundations be destroyed, what can the righteous do?
query: What strategies can I use to discern genuine intentions from flattery?

t: The LORD trieth the righteous: but the wicked and him that loveth violence his soul hateth.
query: How can I actively support those who are oppressed in my community?

t: They speak vanity every one with his neighbour: with flattering lips and with a double heart do they speak.
query: What does it mean to have faith in difficult circumstances?

t: For the oppression of the poor, for the sighing of the needy, now will I arise, saith the LORD; I will set him in safety from him that puffeth at him.
query: How can I express my gratitude for the good in my life?

t: The words of the LORD are pure words: as silver tried in a furnace of earth, purified seven times.
query: What can I learn from those who deny the existence of a higher power?

t: Thou shalt keep them, O LORD, thou shalt preserve them from this generation for ever.
query: How can I seek knowledge and understanding in my daily life?

t: How long wilt thou forget me, O LORD? for ever? how long wilt thou hide thy face from me?
query: What qualities should I strive for to feel a sense of belonging?

t: Consider and hear me, O LORD my God: lighten mine eyes, lest I sleep the sleep of death;
query: How do my actions and values reflect my character to others?

t: The fool hath said in his heart, There is no God. They are corrupt, they have done abominable works, there is none that doeth good.
query: What does it mean to find strength in vulnerability?

t: The LORD looked down from heaven upon the children of men, to see if there were any that did understand, and seek God.
query: How can I maintain hope when facing overwhelming challenges?

t: Ye have shamed the counsel of the poor, because the LORD is his refuge.
query: How do I find courage in my darkest moments?

t: He that backbiteth not with his tongue, nor doeth evil to his neighbour, nor taketh up a reproach against his neighbour.
query: How can I navigate my emotions when feeling threatened?

t: In whose eyes a vile person is contemned; but he honoureth them that fear the LORD. He that sweareth to his own hurt, and changeth not.
query: What role does community play in overcoming personal trials?

t: He that putteth not out his money to usury, nor taketh reward against the innocent. He that doeth these things shall never be moved.
query: How can I balance my own needs with those of others in crisis situations?

t: Preserve me, O God: for in thee do I put my trust.
query: How can I stay resilient in the face of betrayal or disappointment?

t: Their sorrows shall be multiplied that hasten after another god: their drink offerings of blood will I not offer, nor take up their names into my lips.
query: What does it mean to feel truly safe and supported?

t: For I have kept the ways of the LORD, and have not wickedly departed from my God.
query: How can I ensure that my actions align with my values and beliefs?

t: I was also upright before him, and I kept myself from mine iniquity.
query: What does it mean to be rewarded for living righteously?

t: With the merciful thou wilt shew thyself merciful; with an upright man thou wilt shew thyself upright;
query: How can I cultivate a merciful attitude towards others?

t: With the pure thou wilt shew thyself pure; and with the froward thou wilt shew thyself froward.
query: What steps can I take to find light in dark times?

t: As for God, his way is perfect: the word of the LORD is tried: he is a buckler to all those that trust in him.
query: How can I overcome challenges and feel empowered?

t: It is God that girdeth me with strength, and maketh my way perfect.
query: In what ways can I show gratitude for the support I receive?

t: I have pursued mine enemies, and overtaken them: neither did I turn again till they were consumed.
query: How can I maintain my composure in the face of conflict?

t: The strangers shall fade away, and be afraid out of their close places.
query: What does it mean to feel delivered from hardship?

t: Day unto day uttereth speech, and night unto night sheweth knowledge.
query: How do the wonders of nature reflect a higher purpose?

t: His going forth is from the end of the heaven, and his circuit unto the ends of it: and there is nothing hid from the heat thereof.
query: What lessons can I draw from the perfection of moral laws?

t: Moreover by them is thy servant warned: and in keeping of them there is great reward.
query: How can I recognize and learn from my own mistakes?

t: Keep back thy servant also from presumptuous sins; let them not have dominion over me: then shall I be upright, and I shall be innocent from the great transgression.
query: How do I cultivate thoughts and words that reflect my values?

t: The LORD hear thee in the day of trouble; the name of the God of Jacob defend thee;
query: How can I find strength in times of trouble?

t: Remember all thy offerings, and accept thy burnt sacrifice; Selah.
query: What role does community play in supporting each other?

t: Grant thee according to thine own heart, and fulfil all thy counsel.
query: How can I stay hopeful despite feeling overwhelmed?

t: For thou preventest him with the blessings of goodness: thou settest a crown of pure gold on his head.
query: How can I express my faith when faced with doubt or ridicule?

t: For thou hast made him most blessed for ever: thou hast made him exceeding glad with thy countenance.
query: What does it mean to be truly vulnerable and rely on support?

t: Their fruit shalt thou destroy from the earth, and their seed from among the children of men.
query: How can I turn my struggles into opportunities for growth?

t: But thou art holy, O thou that inhabitest the praises of Israel.
query: How can I find comfort in my faith during difficult times?

t: They cried unto thee, and were delivered: they trusted in thee, and were not confounded.
query: What does it mean to find satisfaction in serving others?

t: The LORD is my shepherd; I shall not want.
query: How can I experience peace and restoration in my life?

t: Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil: for thou art with me; thy rod and thy staff they comfort me.
query: What strategies can help me navigate fear during challenging moments?

t: Thou preparest a table before me in the presence of mine enemies: thou anointest my head with oil; my cup runneth over.
query: How can someone feel blessed even in the presence of their adversaries?

t: Surely goodness and mercy shall follow me all the days of my life: and I will dwell in the house of the LORD for ever.
query: What brings a sense of comfort and hope throughout one’s life?

t: The earth is the LORD's, and the fulness thereof; the world, and they that dwell therein.
query: Who owns everything on Earth, including the people living on it?

t: Who shall ascend into the hill of the LORD? or who shall stand in his holy place?
query: What kind of person is worthy of standing in a place of honor or spiritual significance?

t: He that hath clean hands, and a pure heart; who hath not lifted up his soul unto vanity, nor sworn deceitfully.
query: What personal qualities are associated with being upright and truthful?

t: Who is this King of glory? The LORD strong and mighty, the LORD mighty in battle.
query: What qualities make someone a strong and victorious leader?

t: O my God, I trust in thee: let me not be ashamed, let not mine enemies triumph over me.
query: How can someone face enemies without being overwhelmed by shame?

t: Shew me thy ways, O LORD; teach me thy paths.
query: How can one ask for guidance when uncertain about the right path?

t: Remember not the sins of my youth, nor my transgressions: according to thy mercy remember thou me for thy goodness' sake, O LORD.
query: How can people ask for forgiveness for past mistakes?

t: The meek will he guide in judgment: and the meek will he teach his way.
query: What kind of people are most likely to receive guidance during tough decisions?

t: The secret of the LORD is with them that fear him; and he will shew them his covenant.
query: How can someone feel connected to deeper truths or hidden insights?

t: The troubles of my heart are enlarged: O bring thou me out of my distresses.
query: What can someone do when they feel overwhelmed by emotional burdens?

t: Let integrity and uprightness preserve me; for I wait on thee.
query: How can values like integrity and honesty provide stability during difficult times?

t: Examine me, O LORD, and prove me; try my reins and my heart.
query: What might someone say when asking for an honest evaluation of their intentions and character?

t: I have hated the congregation of evil doers; and will not sit with the wicked.
query: What motivates someone to avoid the company of dishonest or harmful people?

t: The LORD is my light and my salvation; whom shall I fear? the LORD is the strength of my life; of whom shall I be afraid?
query: What helps someone stay fearless even in the face of dangerous situations?

t: Though an host should encamp against me, my heart shall not fear: though war should rise against me, in this will I be confident.
query: How can a person stay confident when surrounded by hostility or threats?

t: One thing have I desired of the LORD, that will I seek after; that I may dwell in the house of the LORD all the days of my life, to behold the beauty of the LORD, and to enquire in his temple.
query: What might someone seek to bring them peace and fulfillment for their whole life?

t: And now shall mine head be lifted up above mine enemies round about me: therefore will I offer in his tabernacle sacrifices of joy; I will sing, yea, I will sing praises unto the LORD.
query: What can lift someone’s spirits and inspire joy in the midst of challenges?

t: Have mercy upon me, O LORD, for I am in trouble: mine eye is consumed with grief, yea, my soul and my belly.
query: What does someone ask for when they feel overwhelmed by emotional and physical distress?

t: For my life is spent with grief, and my years with sighing: my strength faileth because of mine iniquity, and my bones are consumed.
query: How can guilt and personal mistakes drain a person’s strength?

t: I am forgotten as a dead man out of mind: I am like a broken vessel.
query: How does it feel to be abandoned and forgotten by others?

t: For I have heard the slander of many: fear was on every side: while they took counsel together against me, they devised to take away my life.
query: What kind of fear arises from hearing slander and knowing others are plotting against you?

t: My times are in thy hand: deliver me from the hand of mine enemies, and from them that persecute me.
query: How does trusting in divine timing bring a sense of relief during difficult times?

t: Make thy face to shine upon thy servant: save me for thy mercies' sake.
query: What does it mean to ask for divine favor in the midst of trouble?

t: Let the lying lips be put to silence; which speak grievous things proudly and contemptuously against the righteous.
query: What do people wish for when they ask for the silence of deceitful voices?

t: Be of good courage, and he shall strengthen your heart, all ye that hope in the LORD.
query: How can courage and hope provide strength during challenging moments?

t: Blessed is he whose transgression is forgiven, whose sin is covered.
query: What kind of happiness comes from being forgiven for past mistakes?

t: When I kept silence, my bones waxed old through my roaring all the day long.
query: How does staying silent about guilt impact a person physically and emotionally?

t: I acknowledge my sin unto thee, and mine iniquity have I not hid. I said, I will confess my transgressions unto the LORD; and thou forgavest the iniquity of my sin. Selah.
query: What happens when someone decides to confess their mistakes openly?

t: Thou art my hiding place; thou shalt preserve me from trouble; thou shalt compass me about with songs of deliverance. Selah.
query: How does the idea of being hidden and protected provide comfort in times of trouble?

t: I will instruct thee and teach thee in the way which thou shalt go: I will guide thee with mine eye.
query: What kind of guidance do people seek to stay on the right path in life?

t: Many sorrows shall be to the wicked: but he that trusteth in the LORD, mercy shall compass him about.
query: How is trust in mercy associated with emotional relief and protection from sorrow?

t: For the word of the LORD is right; and all his works are done in truth.
query: How do the earth’s wonders reflect a sense of divine goodness?

t: By the word of the LORD were the heavens made; and all the host of them by the breath of his mouth.
query: How were the heavens and everything in them brought into existence?

t: For he spake, and it was done; he commanded, and it stood fast.
query: What does it mean for someone to stand in awe of the power of spoken words?

t: The LORD bringeth the counsel of the heathen to nought: he maketh the devices of the people of none effect.
query: How can the plans of people be frustrated by a higher force?

t: He fashioneth their hearts alike; he considereth all their works.
query: What does it mean for every person to be observed and understood, no matter their position?

t: There is no king saved by the multitude of an host: a mighty man is not delivered by much strength.
query: Why is relying on power and strength often a false sense of security?

t: Behold, the eye of the LORD is upon them that fear him, upon them that hope in his mercy;
query: What kind of hope brings comfort during times of need and scarcity?

t: I will bless the LORD at all times: his praise shall continually be in my mouth.
query: How can constant praise bring joy to a person’s life?

t: I sought the LORD, and he heard me, and delivered me from all my fears.
query: How does seeking help alleviate fear and bring peace of mind?

t: They looked unto him, and were lightened: and their faces were not ashamed.
query: What happens to someone’s outlook when they find relief from distress?

t: For he flattereth himself in his own eyes, until his iniquity be found to be hateful.
query: How does self-deception prevent a person from recognizing their faults?

t: The words of his mouth are iniquity and deceit: he hath left off to be wise, and to do good.
query: What happens when someone abandons wisdom and goodness?

t: Thy mercy, O LORD, is in the heavens; and thy faithfulness reacheth unto the clouds.
query: How is divine mercy described as reaching beyond human understanding?

t: How excellent is thy lovingkindness, O God! therefore the children of men put their trust under the shadow of thy wings.
query: What comfort comes from trusting in divine care and protection?

t: For with thee is the fountain of life: in thy light shall we see light.
query: How does recognizing divine kindness inspire trust among people?

t: Fret not thyself because of evildoers, neither be thou envious against the workers of iniquity.
query: Why shouldn't people be envious of those who commit wrongs?

t: Trust in the LORD, and do good; so shalt thou dwell in the land, and verily thou shalt be fed.
query: How can trust in a higher power lead to personal fulfillment?

t: Delight thyself also in the LORD: and he shall give thee the desires of thine heart.
query: What does it mean to delight in divine guidance and receive the desires of one's heart?

t: Cease from anger, and forsake wrath: fret not thyself in any wise to do evil.
query: Why is patience important when witnessing the success of the wicked?

t: But the meek shall inherit the earth; and shall delight themselves in the abundance of peace.
query: How does humility bring lasting peace and abundance?

t: The wicked have drawn out the sword, and have bent their bow, to cast down the poor and needy, and to slay such as be of upright conversation.
query: How does wickedness eventually turn back on those who plot harm?

t: A little that a righteous man hath is better than the riches of many wicked.
query: Why is a righteous life with little more valuable than the riches of the wicked?

t: The LORD knoweth the days of the upright: and their inheritance shall be for ever.
query: What kind of inheritance do the upright receive, especially in hard times?

t: The steps of a good man are ordered by the LORD: and he delighteth in his way.
query: How does divine guidance keep a person from falling, even during hardships?

t: I have been young, and now am old; yet have I not seen the righteous forsaken, nor his seed begging bread.
query: What does it mean that the righteous are never abandoned, even in old age?

t: The mouth of the righteous speaketh wisdom, and his tongue talketh of judgment.
query: Why is wisdom on the lips of the righteous essential for navigating life?

t: Wait on the LORD, and keep his way, and he shall exalt thee to inherit the land: when the wicked are cut off, thou shalt see it.
query: How does waiting on divine timing lead to eventual triumph over wickedness?

t: I have seen the wicked in great power, and spreading himself like a green bay tree.
query: What lesson can be learned from seeing the downfall of someone who once seemed powerful?

t: O lord, rebuke me not in thy wrath: neither chasten me in thy hot displeasure.
query: What impact does divine rebuke have on a person's physical and emotional well-being?

t: For mine iniquities are gone over mine head: as an heavy burden they are too heavy for me.
query: How do personal mistakes feel like a heavy burden that overwhelms the mind?

t: I am troubled; I am bowed down greatly; I go mourning all the day long.
query: What causes deep mourning and sorrow in someone struggling with guilt?

t: And he hath put a new song in my mouth, even praise unto our God: many shall see it, and fear, and shall trust in the LORD.
query: How does divine help offer comfort to those in need?

t: Be pleased, O LORD, to deliver me: O LORD, make haste to help me.
query: What consequences might people face for mocking others?

t: But I am poor and needy; yet the Lord thinketh upon me: thou art my help and my deliverer; make no tarrying, O my God.
query: What might a person feel if they are poor and in need?

t: Blessed is he that considereth the poor: the LORD will deliver him in time of trouble.
query: What are the benefits of caring for the poor?

t: The LORD will strengthen him upon the bed of languishing: thou wilt make all his bed in his sickness.
query: How can someone be strengthened during times of illness?

t: Mine enemies speak evil of me, When shall he die, and his name perish?
query: How might enemies talk behind someone's back?

t: Yea, mine own familiar friend, in whom I trusted, which did eat of my bread, hath lifted up his heel against me.
query: How do enemies devise harm through gossip?

t: By this I know that thou favourest me, because mine enemy doth not triumph over me.
query: How might betrayal feel when it comes from a trusted friend?

t: And as for me, thou upholdest me in mine integrity, and settest me before thy face for ever.
query: What might a person desire after being wronged by others?

t: As the hart panteth after the water brooks, so panteth my soul after thee, O God.
query: How does someone long for something essential, like water?

t: My tears have been my meat day and night, while they continually say unto me, Where is thy God?
query: How can sorrow consume a person throughout the day?

t: Why art thou cast down, O my soul? and why art thou disquieted in me? hope thou in God: for I shall yet praise him for the help of his countenance.
query: Why might someone question their own sadness and seek comfort?

t: Deep calleth unto deep at the noise of thy waterspouts: all thy waves and thy billows are gone over me.
query: How can overwhelming emotions feel like being overcome by nature?

t: I will say unto God my rock, Why hast thou forgotten me? why go I mourning because of the oppression of the enemy?
query: What could make someone feel abandoned in times of oppression?

t: As with a sword in my bones, mine enemies reproach me; while they say daily unto me, Where is thy God?
query: How does constant ridicule from enemies affect a person?

t: Judge me, O God, and plead my cause against an ungodly nation: O deliver me from the deceitful and unjust man.
query: What might someone ask when facing injustice from others?

t: O send out thy light and thy truth: let them lead me; let them bring me unto thy holy hill, and to thy tabernacles.
query: How can light and truth guide someone to where they need to be?

t: We have heard with our ears, O God, our fathers have told us, what work thou didst in their days, in the times of old.
query: What can we learn from stories passed down through generations?

t: For they got not the land in possession by their own sword, neither did their own arm save them: but thy right hand, and thine arm, and the light of thy countenance, because thou hadst a favour unto them.
query: What historical events show people being driven from their lands?

t: For I will not trust in my bow, neither shall my sword save me.
query: How can people win battles without relying on their own strength?

t: Thou makest us to turn back from the enemy: and they which hate us spoil for themselves.
query: How does it feel when efforts lead to defeat instead of victory?

t: Thou hast given us like sheep appointed for meat; and hast scattered us among the heathen.
query: What does it feel like to be scattered among unfamiliar people?

t: Thou makest us a reproach to our neighbours, a scorn and a derision to them that are round about us.
query: How does it feel to be ridiculed by neighboring countries?

t: All this is come upon us; yet have we not forgotten thee, neither have we dealt falsely in thy covenant.
query: What might cause someone to feel constant shame and confusion?

t: Wherefore hidest thou thy face, and forgettest our affliction and our oppression?
query: Why would someone cry out for help when they feel completely broken?

t: My heart is inditing a good matter: I speak of the things which I have made touching the king: my tongue is the pen of a ready writer.
query: How might a person feel inspired to share their thoughts about someone in power?

t: Gird thy sword upon thy thigh, O most mighty, with thy glory and thy majesty.
query: What qualities define a strong and majestic leader?

t: Thine arrows are sharp in the heart of the king's enemies; whereby the people fall under thee.
query: How can a sharp weapon symbolize strength in a leader’s hands?

t: Thou lovest righteousness, and hatest wickedness: therefore God, thy God, hath anointed thee with the oil of gladness above thy fellows.
query: What does it mean for someone to value righteousness and hate wickedness?

t: The king's daughter is all glorious within: her clothing is of wrought gold.
query: How might someone experience joy as they approach a grand and joyful event?

t: God is our refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble.
query: What does it mean to find strength and security in times of trouble?

t: Therefore will not we fear, though the earth be removed, and though the mountains be carried into the midst of the sea;
query: How can we remain calm when facing massive upheavals in life?

t: The heathen raged, the kingdoms were moved: he uttered his voice, the earth melted.
query: What kind of peace can people find when surrounded by chaos?

t: He maketh wars to cease unto the end of the earth; he breaketh the bow, and cutteth the spear in sunder; he burneth the chariot in the fire.
query: How can we understand the impact of wars coming to an end?

t: Be still, and know that I am God: I will be exalted among the heathen, I will be exalted in the earth.
query: What might it mean to simply stop and reflect in moments of crisis?

t: O clap your hands, all ye people; shout unto God with the voice of triumph.
query: How can people express collective joy and triumph?

t: God is gone up with a shout, the LORD with the sound of a trumpet.
query: How can music and praise bring people together in celebration?

t: For God is the King of all the earth: sing ye praises with understanding.
query: What does it mean for a higher power to reign over nations?

t: Great is the LORD, and greatly to be praised in the city of our God, in the mountain of his holiness.
query: Why is the city of God considered a place of beauty and significance?

t: For, lo, the kings were assembled, they passed by together.
query: What causes people to marvel and retreat when faced with something powerful?

t: Fear took hold upon them there, and pain, as of a woman in travail.
query: What metaphor describes the intense pain or fear someone is feeling?

t: Thou breakest the ships of Tarshish with an east wind.
query: What natural force caused the destruction of the ships of Tarshish?

t: Walk about Zion, and go round about her: tell the towers thereof.
query: Why should the daughters of Judah rejoice?

t: Mark ye well her bulwarks, consider her palaces; that ye may tell it to the generation following.
query: What activity is recommended to reflect on the strength and beauty of Zion?

t: My mouth shall speak of wisdom; and the meditation of my heart shall be of understanding.
query: Why is it pointless to fear during difficult times?

t: For he seeth that wise men die, likewise the fool and the brutish person perish, and leave their wealth to others.
query: What is the folly of those who believe their wealth and homes will last forever?

t: Be not thou afraid when one is made rich, when the glory of his house is increased;
query: What is a person compared to when they do not understand their own mortality?

t: For when he dieth he shall carry nothing away: his glory shall not descend after him.
query: What happens to a person's wealth and glory after they die?

t: Man that is in honour, and understandeth not, is like the beasts that perish.
query: How is a person who has honor but no understanding compared to a beast?

t: For every beast of the forest is mine, and the cattle upon a thousand hills.
query: Who owns the cattle on a thousand hills and all the wild beasts?

t: If I were hungry, I would not tell thee: for the world is mine, and the fulness thereof.
query: If someone were hungry, why would they not need to ask for food?

t: Offer unto God thanksgiving; and pay thy vows unto the most High:
query: What is the appropriate offering to give in times of trouble?

t: He causeth the grass to grow for the cattle, and herb for the service of man: that he may bring forth food out of the earth;
query: What does the earth providing food for all creatures reveal about the balance of nature and our role in it?

t: He appointed the moon for seasons: the sun knoweth his going down.
query: How does the moon’s role in marking seasons reflect the rhythms and cycles that govern life?

t: Man goeth forth unto his work and to his labour until the evening.
query: What can the daily rhythm of work and rest teach us about maintaining balance in life?

t: O LORD, how manifold are thy works! in wisdom hast thou made them all: the earth is full of thy riches.
query: How does the diversity and complexity of nature reveal deeper insights into life’s richness?

t: Thou sendest forth thy spirit, they are created: and thou renewest the face of the earth.
query: What can the idea of renewal of the earth teach us about cycles of life and personal renewal?

t: Seek the LORD, and his strength: seek his face evermore.
query: What value can be found in seeking strength and clarity throughout life?

t: Remember his marvellous works that he hath done; his wonders, and the judgments of his mouth;
query: Why is it important to remember the significant events and decisions that have shaped us?

t: He hath remembered his covenant for ever, the word which he commanded to a thousand generations.
query: What can we learn from the idea of a promise lasting for a thousand generations?

t: Whose feet they hurt with fetters: he was laid in iron:
query: What insights can be drawn from Joseph's endurance of suffering and eventual freedom?

t: He made him lord of his house, and ruler of all his substance:
query: What can Joseph’s rise to power after a time of hardship teach us about resilience and opportunity?

t: He spake, and the locusts came, and caterpillers, and that without number,
query: What can the arrival of locusts and caterpillars teach us about the consequences of environmental disasters?

t: He brought them forth also with silver and gold: and there was not one feeble person among their tribes.
query: How might a community thrive when supported by shared wealth and resources?

t: He opened the rock, and the waters gushed out; they ran in the dry places like a river.
query: What can the image of water gushing from a rock symbolize about unexpected sources of help or survival?

t: And gave them the lands of the heathen: and they inherited the labour of the people;
query: How does inheriting land and resources encourage people to observe rules or laws for sustainable living?

t: Blessed are they that keep judgment, and he that doeth righteousness at all times.
query: Why is it important for a person to strive to do what is right at all times?

t: Our fathers understood not thy wonders in Egypt; they remembered not the multitude of thy mercies; but provoked him at the sea, even at the Red sea.
query: What lessons can we learn from the idea that people often forget the help they've received during difficult times?

t: They soon forgat his works; they waited not for his counsel:
query: What are the potential consequences of acting impulsively without seeking guidance?

t: But lusted exceedingly in the wilderness, and tempted God in the desert.
query: How might the fulfillment of a desire sometimes lead to inner dissatisfaction?

t: They made a calf in Horeb, and worshipped the molten image.
query: What can the worship of a golden calf teach us about the dangers of materialism and losing sight of greater values?

t: Thus they provoked him to anger with their inventions: and the plague brake in upon them.
query: What are the risks of following harmful practices or beliefs, as seen in the sacrifices to false idols?

t: Therefore was the wrath of the LORD kindled against his people, insomuch that he abhorred his own inheritance.
query: What are the potential consequences when a group or nation turns away from their core principles?

t: Then they cried unto the LORD in their trouble, and he delivered them out of their distresses.
query: What can we learn from those who cry out for help in times of desperation?

t: For he satisfieth the longing soul, and filleth the hungry soul with goodness.
query: How does providing for the needs of a longing or hungry soul relate to personal fulfillment?

t: He brought them out of darkness and the shadow of death, and brake their bands in sunder.
query: What does being brought out of darkness symbolize in terms of overcoming adversity or despair?

t: Fools because of their transgression, and because of their iniquities, are afflicted.
query: What can be learned from the connection between personal choices and the suffering that follows?

t: They that go down to the sea in ships, that do business in great waters;
query: How does the experience of those who do business at sea reflect the unpredictability of life?

t: He maketh the storm a calm, so that the waves thereof are still.
query: What insights can we draw from the calming of a storm after a period of turmoil?

t: He turneth the wilderness into a standing water, and dry ground into watersprings.
query: What can the transformation of barren land into fertile ground teach us about renewal and growth?

t: Yet setteth he the poor on high from affliction, and maketh him families like a flock.
query: What might a person experience after enduring affliction?

t: The righteous shall see it, and rejoice: and all iniquity shall stop her mouth.
query: How would righteous people react to the downfall of iniquity?

t: Whoso is wise, and will observe these things, even they shall understand the lovingkindness of the LORD.
query: What can people gain from observing life's events with wisdom?

t: O god, my heart is fixed; I will sing and give praise, even with my glory.
query: What does someone with a steadfast heart express through praise?

t: Awake, psaltery and harp: I myself will awake early.
query: What would motivate a person to wake up early with musical instruments?

t: I will praise thee, O LORD, among the people: and I will sing praises unto thee among the nations.
query: Why would someone praise the Lord publicly?

t: For thy mercy is great above the heavens: and thy truth reacheth unto the clouds.
query: How is God's mercy and truth described?

t: Be thou exalted, O God, above the heavens: and thy glory above all the earth;
query: What desire does a person express for God's exaltation?

t: That thy beloved may be delivered: save with thy right hand, and answer me.
query: What request is made for deliverance and divine intervention?

t: Give us help from trouble: for vain is the help of man.
query: Why does a person feel that human help is insufficient in times of trouble?

t: Through God we shall do valiantly: for he it is that shall tread down our enemies.
query: What does a person attribute victory to?

t: Hold not thy peace, O God of my praise;
query: What is a common plea when facing false accusations and deceit?

t: They compassed me about also with words of hatred; and fought against me without a cause.
query: How does a person respond to adversaries despite being hated without cause?

t: Because that he remembered not to shew mercy, but persecuted the poor and needy man, that he might even slay the broken in heart.
query: Why might someone face severe consequences for persecuting the poor and broken-hearted?

t: But do thou for me, O GOD the Lord, for thy name's sake: because thy mercy is good, deliver thou me.
query: What plea is made to God when someone feels wounded and needy?

t: For I am poor and needy, and my heart is wounded within me.
query: What might a person feel when they describe themselves as both poor and wounded?

t: I am gone like the shadow when it declineth: I am tossed up and down as the locust.
query: How does a person describe the fleeting nature of their life?

t: My knees are weak through fasting; and my flesh faileth of fatness.
query: What physical effects might someone experience from fasting and hardship?

t: Help me, O LORD my God: O save me according to thy mercy:
query: Why does someone appeal for God's help when feeling vulnerable?

t: That they may know that this is thy hand; that thou, LORD, hast done it.
query: What is the purpose of divine intervention, according to a person seeking deliverance?

t: Let them curse, but bless thou: when they arise, let them be ashamed; but let thy servant rejoice.
query: How does a person reconcile being cursed by others yet seeking blessings from God?

t: I will greatly praise the LORD with my mouth; yea, I will praise him among the multitude.
query: How does a person express gratitude to God publicly?

t: For he shall stand at the right hand of the poor, to save him from those that condemn his soul.
query: In what way does God stand with the poor, according to someone in need?

t: The LORD said unto my Lord, Sit thou at my right hand, until I make thine enemies thy footstool.
query: What promise does God make about the defeat of enemies?

t: The LORD hath sworn, and will not repent, Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchizedek.
query: What significance is given to a priestly order that lasts forever?

t: The works of the LORD are great, sought out of all them that have pleasure therein.
query: How do people perceive the works of the Lord?

t: He hath made his wonderful works to be remembered: the LORD is gracious and full of compassion.
query: What qualities does the Lord show through His works?

t: He sent redemption unto his people: he hath commanded his covenant for ever: holy and reverend is his name.
query: What does God provide through His covenant with His people?

t: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom: a good understanding have all they that do his commandments: his praise endureth for ever.
query: How is the fear of the Lord related to wisdom?

t: Praise ye the LORD. Blessed is the man that feareth the LORD, that delighteth greatly in his commandments.
query: What are the characteristics of someone who delights in God's commandments?

t: Unto the upright there ariseth light in the darkness: he is gracious, and full of compassion, and righteous.
query: How is an upright person described in times of darkness?

t: He shall not be afraid of evil tidings: his heart is fixed, trusting in the LORD.
query: Why is a righteous person not afraid of bad news?

t: He hath dispersed, he hath given to the poor; his righteousness endureth for ever; his horn shall be exalted with honour.
query: How is generosity towards the poor viewed in relation to righteousness?

t: From the rising of the sun unto the going down of the same the LORD's name is to be praised.
query: When is the name of the Lord to be praised?

t: Who is like unto the LORD our God, who dwelleth on high,
query: What makes the Lord unique in His high position?

t: He raiseth up the poor out of the dust, and lifteth the needy out of the dunghill;
query: How does God elevate the poor and the needy?

t: He maketh the barren woman to keep house, and to be a joyful mother of children. Praise ye the LORD.
query: What does God do for a barren woman?

t: What ailed thee, O thou sea, that thou fleddest? thou Jordan, that thou wast driven back?
query: What causes natural elements like the sea and river to react so dramatically?

t: Tremble, thou earth, at the presence of the Lord, at the presence of the God of Jacob;
query: What effect does God's presence have on the earth?

t: Not unto us, O LORD, not unto us, but unto thy name give glory, for thy mercy, and for thy truth's sake.
query: What reason does a person give for glorifying God's name instead of their own?

t: Wherefore should the heathen say, Where is now their God?
query: What question might be asked by those who doubt God's presence?

t: Their idols are silver and gold, the work of men's hands.
query: What are idols made of according to someone who critiques them?

t: They have mouths, but they speak not: eyes have they, but they see not:
query: Why are idols viewed as powerless, based on their inability to speak or see?

t: They that make them are like unto them; so is every one that trusteth in them.
query: How does a person compare those who make and trust in idols to the idols themselves?

t: O Israel, trust thou in the LORD: he is their help and their shield.
query: Why does Israel trust in the Lord?

t: The sorrows of death compassed me, and the pains of hell gat hold upon me: I found trouble and sorrow.
query: What emotions surrounded me when I faced danger?

t: The LORD preserveth the simple: I was brought low, and he helped me.
query: Who does the Lord assist when they are in trouble?

t: For thou hast delivered my soul from death, mine eyes from tears, and my feet from falling.
query: What has been delivered from death and sorrow?

t: I said in my haste, All men are liars.
query: What did I say in a moment of frustration about other people?

t: The LORD is on my side; I will not fear: what can man do unto me?
query: Why should I not be afraid of others?

t: It is better to trust in the LORD than to put confidence in man.
query: Is it better to rely on people or something greater?

t: All nations compassed me about: but in the name of the LORD will I destroy them.
query: Is trusting in authority figures less reliable than trusting in something higher?

t: Thou hast thrust sore at me that I might fall: but the LORD helped me.
query: What did I do after being attacked but helped?

t: The stone which the builders refused is become the head stone of the corner.
query: What significance does the rejected stone hold?

t: This is the day which the LORD hath made; we will rejoice and be glad in it.
query: Why is this day special, and what should my attitude be?

t: Blessed are the undefiled in the way, who walk in the law of the LORD.
query: What kind of people are considered fortunate in their actions?

t: Blessed are they that keep his testimonies, and that seek him with the whole heart.
query: What does seeking with full dedication result in?

t: Wherewithal shall a young man cleanse his way? by taking heed thereto according to thy word.
query: How can a young person keep their path free of mistakes?

t: Thy word have I hid in mine heart, that I might not sin against thee.
query: Why is it important to hold onto certain teachings?

t: Open thou mine eyes, that I may behold wondrous things out of thy law.
query: What do I want to discover by gaining clarity?

t: My soul melteth for heaviness: strengthen thou me according unto thy word.
query: What emotion is weighing heavily on me, and what do I need?

t: I will run the way of thy commandments, when thou shalt enlarge my heart.
query: What will I do when I feel free and motivated?

t: Teach me, O LORD, the way of thy statutes; and I shall keep it unto the end.
query: What am I asking for guidance in understanding?

t: Make me to go in the path of thy commandments; for therein do I delight.
query: What do I take joy in following?

t: Turn away mine eyes from beholding vanity; and quicken thou me in thy way.
query: What should I avoid focusing on, and how will it help me?

t: Behold, I have longed after thy precepts: quicken me in thy righteousness.
query: What do I long for, and what can restore me?

t: So shall I have wherewith to answer him that reproacheth me: for I trust in thy word.
query: How do I respond to those who criticize me?

t: And I will walk at liberty: for I seek thy precepts.
query: What brings me a sense of freedom?

t: I will speak of thy testimonies also before kings, and will not be ashamed.
query: How will I feel when speaking openly, even before powerful people?

t: This is my comfort in my affliction: for thy word hath quickened me.
query: What has brought me comfort during difficult times?

t: The proud have had me greatly in derision: yet have I not declined from thy law.
query: How do I handle mockery or derision from others?

t: This I had, because I kept thy precepts.
query: Why have I stayed committed to my path?

t: I thought on my ways, and turned my feet unto thy testimonies.
query: What did I do after reflecting on my actions?

t: The bands of the wicked have robbed me: but I have not forgotten thy law.
query: How did I react when wronged by others?

t: I am a companion of all them that fear thee, and of them that keep thy precepts.
query: Who are the types of people I consider my companions?

t: Teach me good judgment and knowledge: for I have believed thy commandments.
query: What am I seeking when I ask for better judgment?

t: Before I was afflicted I went astray: but now have I kept thy word.
query: What did I realize about my behavior after facing hardship?

t: It is good for me that I have been afflicted; that I might learn thy statutes.
query: What did I gain from going through difficulties?

t: The law of thy mouth is better unto me than thousands of gold and silver.
query: How do I compare learning to wealth?

t: Thy hands have made me and fashioned me: give me understanding, that I may learn thy commandments.
query: What do I hope to gain from understanding my own existence?

t: They that fear thee will be glad when they see me; because I have hoped in thy word.
query: What reaction do others have when they see my commitment?

t: Let the proud be ashamed; for they dealt perversely with me without a cause: but I will meditate in thy precepts.
query: How should those who treated me unfairly feel?

t: My soul fainteth for thy salvation: but I hope in thy word.
query: What do I long for when I feel faint or weak?

t: How many are the days of thy servant? when wilt thou execute judgment on them that persecute me?
query: What question do I ask when facing persecution?

t: All thy commandments are faithful: they persecute me wrongfully; help thou me.
query: What is my reaction to being wrongfully persecuted?

t: Unless thy law had been my delights, I should then have perished in mine affliction.
query: What would have happened to me if I hadn’t found comfort in something greater?

t: I will never forget thy precepts: for with them thou hast quickened me.
query: Why will I never forget certain principles?

t: The wicked have waited for me to destroy me: but I will consider thy testimonies.
query: How do I handle threats from those who want to harm me?

t: I have seen an end of all perfection: but thy commandment is exceeding broad.
query: What realization have I come to about perfection?

t: O how I love thy law! it is my meditation all the day.
query: What is my attitude toward learning?

t: Thou through thy commandments hast made me wiser than mine enemies: for they are ever with me.
query: How has learning made me more effective than my adversaries?

t: I have more understanding than all my teachers: for thy testimonies are my meditation.
query: What allows me to understand more than my teachers?

t: How sweet are thy words unto my taste! yea, sweeter than honey to my mouth!
query: How do I describe the value of learning and wisdom?

t: Thy word is a lamp unto my feet, and a light unto my path.
query: What helps guide me through life?

t: I am afflicted very much: quicken me, O LORD, according unto thy word.
query: How do I react when I am heavily afflicted?

t: The wicked have laid a snare for me: yet I erred not from thy precepts.
query: What do I avoid, even when others set traps for me?

t: Thy testimonies have I taken as an heritage for ever: for they are the rejoicing of my heart.
query: What do I treasure most in life?

t: I hate vain thoughts: but thy law do I love.
query: What is my attitude towards empty or vain thoughts?

t: Thou art my hiding place and my shield: I hope in thy word.
query: Where do I find protection and hope?

t: Uphold me according unto thy word, that I may live: and let me not be ashamed of my hope.
query: How do I maintain hope and avoid feeling ashamed?

t: Mine eyes fail for thy salvation, and for the word of thy righteousness.
query: What do I feel when waiting for fairness and justice?

t: The entrance of thy words giveth light; it giveth understanding unto the simple.
query: What does knowledge provide to those who seek it?

t: Rivers of waters run down mine eyes, because they keep not thy law.
query: Why do I feel overwhelmed with sorrow?

t: My zeal hath consumed me, because mine enemies have forgotten thy words.
query: What fuels my passion and drive?

t: I am small and despised: yet do not I forget thy precepts.
query: How do I handle feeling insignificant?

t: Thy righteousness is an everlasting righteousness, and thy law is the truth.
query: What is said to be true and everlasting?

t: Trouble and anguish have taken hold on me: yet thy commandments are my delights.
query: How do I find joy during times of trouble?

t: The righteousness of thy testimonies is everlasting: give me understanding, and I shall live.
query: What do I need to live and thrive?

t: They draw nigh that follow after mischief: they are far from thy law.
query: What kind of people are getting closer to me?

t: Thou art near, O LORD; and all thy commandments are truth.
query: What is considered always near and true?

t: Concerning thy testimonies, I have known of old that thou hast founded them for ever.
query: How long have I known about the principles that guide me?

t: Many are my persecutors and mine enemies; yet do I not decline from thy testimonies.
query: How do I stay committed even when many oppose me?

t: I beheld the transgressors, and was grieved; because they kept not thy word.
query: What is my reaction when I see people breaking the rules?

t: I rejoice at thy word, as one that findeth great spoil.
query: How do I feel when I discover something valuable?

t: I hate and abhor lying: but thy law do I love.
query: What is my attitude toward falsehood?

t: Great peace have they which love thy law: and nothing shall offend them.
query: What brings me great peace and resilience?

t: My soul hath kept thy testimonies; and I love them exceedingly.
query: What have I kept close to me and loved deeply?

t: I have longed for thy salvation, O LORD; and thy law is my delight.
query: What have I longed for, and what do I take joy in?

t: Deliver my soul, O LORD, from lying lips, and from a deceitful tongue.
query: What do I want to be delivered from?

t: My soul hath long dwelt with him that hateth peace.
query: How long have I been surrounded by those who dislike peace?

t: I am for peace: but when I speak, they are for war.
query: What is my stance when others prefer conflict?

t: I will lift up mine eyes unto the hills, from whence cometh my help.
query: Where do I look for help?

t: He will not suffer thy foot to be moved: he that keepeth thee will not slumber.
query: Who ensures that I remain steady?

t: The sun shall not smite thee by day, nor the moon by night.
query: What protects me from harm during the day and night?

t: The LORD shall preserve thy going out and thy coming in from this time forth, and even for evermore.
query: How long will I be watched over when I go about my life?

t: I was glad when they said unto me, Let us go into the house of the LORD.
query: How did I feel when invited to a significant place?

t: Jerusalem is builded as a city that is compact together:
query: How is a certain city described in terms of its structure?

t: Peace be within thy walls, and prosperity within thy palaces.
query: What do I wish for a specific place?

t: For my brethren and companions' sakes, I will now say, Peace be within thee.
query: Why do I desire peace?

t: Our soul is exceedingly filled with the scorning of those that are at ease, and with the contempt of the proud.
query: What have I been filled with after being treated with contempt?

t: Our soul is escaped as a bird out of the snare of the fowlers: the snare is broken, and we are escaped.
query: How do I feel after escaping a dangerous situation?

t: They that trust in the LORD shall be as mount Zion, which cannot be removed, but abideth for ever.
query: How does someone who trusts in the right principles compare to something immovable?

t: For the rod of the wicked shall not rest upon the lot of the righteous; lest the righteous put forth their hands unto iniquity.
query: What won't remain over those who are virtuous?

t: Then was our mouth filled with laughter, and our tongue with singing: then said they among the heathen, The LORD hath done great things for them.
query: What was my reaction when I experienced something incredible?

t: They that sow in tears shall reap in joy.
query: What can be expected after enduring hardship?

t: He that goeth forth and weepeth, bearing precious seed, shall doubtless come again with rejoicing, bringing his sheaves with him.
query: How does someone return after a period of sorrow with something precious?

t: Except the LORD build the house, they labour in vain that build it: except the LORD keep the city, the watchman waketh but in vain.
query: What happens if a project is undertaken without proper foundation?

t: It is vain for you to rise up early, to sit up late, to eat the bread of sorrows: for so he giveth his beloved sleep.
query: Why is it unnecessary to overwork and worry?

t: Happy is the man that hath his quiver full of them: they shall not be ashamed, but they shall speak with the enemies in the gate.
query: How does a person with many children feel when facing challenges?

t: For thou shalt eat the labour of thine hands: happy shalt thou be, and it shall be well with thee.
query: What does someone who follows the right path get to enjoy?

t: Thy wife shall be as a fruitful vine by the sides of thine house: thy children like olive plants round about thy table.
query: How is a wife described in relation to a household?

t: The LORD shall bless thee out of Zion: and thou shalt see the good of Jerusalem all the days of thy life.
query: What will I get to see as a sign of prosperity in my family?

t: Many a time have they afflicted me from my youth: yet they have not prevailed against me.
query: What is said about the persistence of challenges throughout life?

t: The LORD is righteous: he hath cut asunder the cords of the wicked.
query: What has happened to those who acted with cruelty?

t: O lord, thou hast searched me, and known me.
query: Is there anyone who truly knows me inside and out?

t: Thou knowest my downsitting and mine uprising, thou understandest my thought afar off.
query: Can anyone understand my thoughts before I even speak?

t: Whither shall I go from thy spirit? or whither shall I flee from thy presence?
query: Is there anywhere I can go to escape being watched or judged?

t: I will praise thee; for I am fearfully and wonderfully made: marvellous are thy works; and that my soul knoweth right well.
query: How can I appreciate myself more and realize my worth?

t: Deliver me, O LORD, from the evil man: preserve me from the violent man;
query: What should I do when facing violent or manipulative people?

t: They have sharpened their tongues like a serpent; adders' poison is under their lips. Selah.
query: How can I deal with people who speak with venomous intent?

t: Set a watch, O LORD, before my mouth; keep the door of my lips.
query: How can I be more careful about the words I use?

t: Incline not my heart to any evil thing, to practise wicked works with men that work iniquity: and let me not eat of their dainties.
query: How can I avoid the influence of people who do evil?

t: I poured out my complaint before him; I shewed before him my trouble.
query: What can I do when I feel overwhelmed with problems and don't know where to turn?

t: I looked on my right hand, and beheld, but there was no man that would know me: refuge failed me; no man cared for my soul.
query: How can I cope with feeling abandoned and alone in my struggles?

t: Man is like to vanity: his days are as a shadow that passeth away.
query: What does it mean that life feels so fleeting and temporary?

t: The LORD is gracious, and full of compassion; slow to anger, and of great mercy.
query: How can I practice more compassion and patience with others?

t: The LORD is good to all: and his tender mercies are over all his works.
query: Is there goodness in the world for everyone, even those who seem undeserving?

t: The LORD upholdeth all that fall, and raiseth up all those that be bowed down.
query: How can I recover when I feel like I've hit rock bottom?

t: Put not your trust in princes, nor in the son of man, in whom there is no help.
query: Can I rely on powerful or influential people to help me?

t: Happy is he that hath the God of Jacob for his help, whose hope is in the LORD his God:
query: Who can I trust for true help and hope in difficult times?

t: He healeth the broken in heart, and bindeth up their wounds.
query: How can I heal when my heart feels broken?

t: He telleth the number of the stars; he calleth them all by their names.
query: How vast is the universe and how much can we really understand?

t: The LORD lifteth up the meek: he casteth the wicked down to the ground.
query: What happens to people who are humble compared to those who act wickedly?

t: Who covereth the heaven with clouds, who prepareth rain for the earth, who maketh grass to grow upon the mountains.
query: How does nature get its life and sustenance?

t: He delighteth not in the strength of the horse: he taketh not pleasure in the legs of a man.
query: What is more important than physical strength or power?

t: Let them praise the name of the LORD: for he commanded, and they were created.
query: Why does creation exist, and who is responsible for it?

t: Kings of the earth, and all people; princes, and all judges of the earth:
query: Who should give praise regardless of rank, age, or status?

t: Let every thing that hath breath praise the LORD. Praise ye the LORD.
query: What is the purpose of life for all living beings?
